{{Infobox Weapon | name=TAM | image=[[Image:TAM snorkel.JPG|300px]] | caption=Argentine Army TAM |origin=Argentina; Germany |type=[[Main battle tank]] |is_vehicle=yes |service= from 1983–present |used_by= [[Argentina]] |wars= |designer= |manufacturer= |unit_cost= 1,500,000 USD (1983 export price) |production_date=1979–91, 1994–95 |number= 280 |variants= | length={{convert|6.75|m|ftin|abbr=on}} | width={{convert|3.25|m|ftin|abbr=on}} | height={{convert|2.42|m|ftin|abbr=on}} | weight={{convert|30.5|t|abbr=on}} | suspension=[[Torsion-bar]] | speed={{convert|75|km/h|mph|abbr=on}} | vehicle_range={{convert|590|km|abbr=on}}, {{convert|800|km|abbr=on}} with auxiliary fuel tanks | primary_armament={{convert|105|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} [[Royal Ordnance L7|FM K.4 ''Modelo'' 1L]] | secondary_armament= 2×{{convert|7.62|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} machine gun | armour= | engine= [[MTU Friedrichshafen|MTU]]-MB 833 Ka-500 [[Straight-six engine|6-cylinder]] {{convert|22.4|L|cuin|abbr=on}} [[Diesel engine|diesel]] | engine_power={{convert|720|hp|disp=flip|abbr=on}} | pw_ratio=24 hp/tonne | crew=4 }} {{Cold War tanks}} {{Post-Cold War tanks}} The '''Tanque Argentino Mediano''' ('''TAM'''; [[English language|English]]: ''Argentine Medium Tank'') is the [[main battle tank]] in service with the [[Argentine Army]]. Lacking the experience and resources to design a tank, the [[Ministry of Defense (Argentina)|Argentine Ministry of Defense]] contracted German company [[Thyssen-Henschel]]. The vehicle was developed by a German and [[Argentina|Argentine]] team of engineers, and was based on the German [[Marder (IFV)|Marder infantry fighting vehicle]]. The TAM met the Argentine Army's requirement for a modern, lightweight and fast tank with a low silhouette and sufficient firepower to defeat contemporary armored threats. Development began in 1974 and resulted in the construction of three prototypes by early 1977 and full-scale production by 1979. Assembly took place at the local {{convert|9600|m2|adj=on|sp=us}} TAMSE plant, founded for the purpose by the Argentine government. Economic difficulties halted production in 1983, but manufacturing began anew in 1994 until the army's order of 200 tanks was fulfilled. [[Image:TAM VCA.JPG|right|thumb|Argentine TAM VCA 155 Palmaria]] [[Image:VCTP.JPG|thumb|right|A TAM VCTP, May 2008]] The TAM series includes seven different variants, such as a {{convert|155|mm|in|adj=on|abbr=in}} [[self-propelled howitzer]] and a self-propelled mortar vehicle. In total, over 280 such vehicles were built, including armored personnel carriers, artillery and mortar pieces. The TAM and VCTP (Infantry Fighting Vehicles based on the TAM chassis) were manufactured for the [[Peruvian Army]], only to be integrated into the Argentine Army when Peru canceled the contract. The TAM also competed for other export orders, but the TAM was ultimately not exported. The TAM has never seen combat, although 17 VCTP were deployed to [[Croatia]] for the United Nations [[UNPROFOR]] peacekeeping mission. ==Development== During the 1960s Argentina sought to replace its aging fleet of tanks, which included [[United Kingdom|British]] [[Sherman Firefly|Sherman V Firefly tanks]] and American [[M3 Half-track|M3A1 half-tracks]] dating from shortly after the Second World War. In their attempts to procure equipment from the United States, Argentina could only secure 50 [[M41 Walker Bulldog]]s (undelivered) and 250 [[M113 Armored Personnel Carrier|M113 armored personnel carriers]]. When the United States turned down requests for further equipment, the Argentine government turned to the other side of the Atlantic, putting their "Plan Europa" (Plan Europe) into action. It was hoped that European technology could stimulate Argentine industry so the country could produce its own armaments in the future. Argentina procured 80 [[AMX-13]] light tanks, as well as 180 [[AMX-VCI]]s and 24 [[Mk F3 155mm|AMX-155 F3s]], from the French government, manufacturing around 40 AMX-13s and 60 AMX-VCIs at home. The French [[AMX-30]] and German [[Leopard 1]] were also examined as possible replacements for the Argentine Sherman fleet.{{Sfn | de Mazarrasa | 1996 | pp = 9–10}} In 1973 the Argentine Ministry of Defense drew up a series of requirements for a tank to enter service in the 1980s. The armored vehicle would weigh no more than {{convert|30|t|1}}, move at a maximum speed of {{convert|70|km/h|mph|abbr=on}}, and cover at least {{convert|500|km|mi|abbr=on}} on roads. It would be armed with a modern 105 mm main gun, two [[machine gun]]s, and grenade launchers. The tank designers also had to take into account Argentina's existing infrastructure, including railroad capacity, bridges and road capacity, as well as the country's varied terrain. In late 1973 the ''Proyecto de Tanque Argentino Mediano'' (Medium Argentine Tank Project) was founded with the goal of designing and developing a tank for the Argentine Army. Lacking the experience and the necessary technology, the Argentine government sought collaboration with a foreign company, resulting in a contract with the German company Thyssen-Henschel. The contract called for a transfer of technology resulting in a program to develop a tank in line with the government's requirements and under a technical team that included both German and Argentine engineers. The hull of the German Marder armored personnel carrier was used,{{Sfn | de Mazarrasa | 1996 | pp = 11–15}} and the chassis was strengthened to support the increased weight of the TAM.{{Sfn | Foss | 2004 | p = 53}} Two prototypes were manufactured in late 1976 and early 1977,{{Sfn | Bishop | 2006 | p = 218}} which were put through extensive testing for two years and over a road range of {{convert|10,000|km|mi|abbr=on}}. Simultaneously, another prototype was manufactured to further the investigation of the new vehicle{{Sfn | de Mazarrasa | 1996 | pp = 11–15}} and complete the three prototypes as agreed in the contract.{{Sfn | Miller | 2000 | p = 10}} The new tank's firepower requirements were met by fitting a British [[Royal Ordnance L7| Royal Ordnance L7A1]] {{convert|105|mm|in|2|adj=on|abbr=in}} main gun. This gun was later replaced by the modified L7A2 and finally by [[Rheinmetall]]'s Rh-105-30 {{convert|105|mm|in|2|adj=on|abbr=in}} gun. This gun is manufactured in Argentina as the FM K.4 ''Modelo'' 1L.{{Sfn | de Mazarrasa | 1996 | p = 27}} The Rh-105-30's advantages include low weight, compact size and increased lethality.{{cite web| url= http://www.rheinmetall-defence.com/index.php?fid=1447&lang=3&pdb=1 |title = 105 mm Tank Guns – Rh 105-20 / Rh 105-30 | publisher = Rheinmetall Defence |work = Weapons and Ammunition | accessdate = 6 January 2008}} Unlike the Rh-105-30, the FM K.4 does not have a [[muzzle brake]].{{Sfn | de Mazarrasa | 1996 | p = 27}} The locally built cannon can be elevated to 18 degrees or depressed to -7 degrees on the TAM.{{Sfn | Foss | 2006 | p = 10}} The gun's hydraulic recoil mechanism has an extended range of {{convert|580|mm|in|1|abbr=in}} to absorb the {{convert|34|t|adj=on}} recoil force.{{Sfn | de Mazarrasa | 1996 | p = 28}} It is designed to fire the M735A1 [[Kinetic energy penetrator|armor-piercing fin-stabilized discarding sabot]], which can penetrate a maximum of {{convert|370|mm|in|1|abbr=in}} at {{convert|1,000|m|yd|sp=us}}. It can also fire [[High-explosive anti-tank warhead|high-explosive anti-tank]] rounds, [[high-explosive squash head]] and smoke rounds.{{Sfn | de Mazarrasa | 1996 | p = 30}} The tank's secondary armaments include a [[coaxial weapon|co-axial]] {{convert|7.62|mm|in|2|adj=on|abbr=in}} [[FN MAG]] 60-40 [[general purpose machine gun]] and a second FN MAG 60-20 mounted on the TAM's turret roof{{Sfn | de Mazarrasa | 1996 | p = 29}} as an anti-aircraft machine gun.{{Sfn | Foss | 2006 | p = 10}} The [[fire control system]] includes a [[Nd:YAG laser]] with a range of {{convert|9,900|m|ft|sigfig=4|sp=us}} and a FLER-HG ballistic computer to compute the gun's fire solutions—helping the gunner aim and hit the target. The tank commander uses a [[Carl Zeiss AG|Zeiss]] PERI-R/TA panoramic [[periscope]], with a 2x and 8x [[Zoom lens|zoom]].{{Sfn | de Mazarrasa | 1996 | p = 32}} [[Image:TAM RC Tan 8.JPG|right|thumb|TAM with its snorkel installed during an Argentine Army exposition]] The TAM's engine requirements included low weight and volume, but with a fast rate of acceleration and high reliability. The program chose [[MTU Friedrichshafen|MTU]]'s MB-833 Ka 500 diesel engine, producing {{convert|720|hp|abbr=on|disp=flip}} at 2,400 [[Revolutions per minute|rpm]].{{Sfn | Foss | 2004 | p = 53}} This gives the TAM a power-to-weight ratio of 24 horsepower per tonne and a maximum speed of {{convert|75|km/h|mph|abbr=on}} on road and {{convert|40|km/h|mph|abbr=on}} off-road.{{Sfn | de Mazarrasa | 1996 | pp = 33–35}} With a {{convert|680|liter|USgal impgal|adj=on|abbr=off}} internal fuel tank, the TAM can travel {{convert|500|km|mi|abbr=on}}. Its range is extended to {{convert|900|km|mi|sp=us}} if the vehicle is equipped with two {{convert|200|liter|USgal impgal|adj=on}} external fuel tanks.{{Sfn | Miller | 2000 | p = 11}} The TAM's transmission is a [[Renk]] HSWL-204 automatic, with a [[torque converter|hydrodynamic torque converter]].{{Sfn | de Mazarrasa | 1996 | pp = 33–35}} A double brake system includes hydraulic disk brakes on the roadwheels, and the suspension is a [[Torsion beam suspension|torsion bar]].{{Sfn | Foss | 2004 | p = 54}} The TAM's survivability is related to its low profile turret, based on that of the Leopard 1A4s and the [[Leopard 2]],{{Sfn | de Mazarrasa | 1996 | p = 24}} and its physical armor array. It has {{convert|50|mm|in|2|abbr=in}} at 75 degrees on the [[glacis]] plate and 32 degrees on the vehicle's sides. This offers protection against anti-armor shells from up to {{convert|35|mm|in|2|adj=on|abbr=in}} guns.{{Sfn | de Mazarrasa | 1996 | p = 36}} The turret front is protected by {{convert|50|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} of steel armor at an angle of 32 degrees.{{Sfn | de Mazarrasa | 1996 | p = 60}} Although the tank's weight and armor protection are light compared to other main battle tanks, it has the advantage of better tactical mobility over the nation's terrain.{{Sfn | Schneider | 2006 | p = 59}} As a private venture, Thyssen-Henschel built a fourth prototype designated TH 301. Completed in 1978, it added a PERI R12 periscope, originally designed for the [[Leopard 1]]A4, for the tank commander. The gunner and loader each received a day periscope as well. To enable the crew to fire effectively at night, a [[low light level television]] (LLLTV) camera, which moved in elevation with the main gun, was fitted to the [[Gun mantlet|mantlet]]. Furthermore, the tank received a more powerful {{convert |750|PS|disp=flip|abbr = in}} engine.{{Sfn | Foss | 2004 | p = 54}} The improvement program also made provisions to increase the thickness of the armor for additional protection.{{Sfn | Foss | 2006 | p = 10}} In 2010, a modernization program was announced. Israeli defense contractor [[Elbit Systems]] was chosen to provide 3-axis gyro-stabilization, and most probably the [[Royal Ordnance L7|L7A2 105 mm cannon]] will be replaced with a more powerful 120 mm cannon, like the [[Rheinmetall 120 mm gun|L44 120 mm Cannon]].{{Citation | place = [[Argentine|AR]] | publisher = Ministry of Defense | url = http://www.mindef.gov.ar/info.asp?Id=1496 | title = Garré anunció que se modernizará el tanque argentino mediano | language = es | trans_title = Garré announced that the medium Argentinian tank will be modernised}}. The first TAM unit upgraded by Elbit Systems was delivered in March 2013.{{Citation | date = 7 March 2013 | title = El Ejército Argentino recibe el primer tanque TAM modernizado por Elbit | trans_title = The Argentine Army receives first TAM tank modernized by Elbit | work = Infodefensa | url = http://www.infodefensa.com/latam/2013/03/07/noticia-el-ejercito-argentino-recibe-el-primer-tanque-tam-modernizado-por-elbit.html | publisher = IDS, Información de Defensa y Seguridad | language = es}} ==Variants== A number of variants were built on the same chassis as the TAM tank. The original program called for the design of an [[infantry fighting vehicle]], and in 1977 the program finished manufacturing the prototype of the ''Vehículo de Combate Transporte de Personal'' (Personnel Transport Combat Vehicle), or VCTP.{{Sfn | de Mazarrasa | 1996 | pp = 11–15}} The VCTP is able to transport a squad of 12 men, including the squad leader and nine riflemen. The squad leader is situated in the turret of the vehicle; one rifleman sits behind him and another six are seated in the chassis, the eighth manning the hull machine gun and the ninth situated in the turret with the gunner. All personnel can fire their weapons from inside the vehicle, and the VCTP's turret is armed with Rheinmetall's Rh-202 {{convert|20|mm|in|2|adj=on|abbr=in}} [[autocannon]]. The VCTP holds 880 rounds for the autocannon, including subcaliber armor-piercing DM63 rounds. It is also armed with a 7.62 mm FN MAG 60-20 [[machine gun]] mounted on the turret roof. Infantry can dismount through a door on the rear of the hull.{{Sfn | de Mazarrasa | 1996 | pp = 40–43}} The commander has a day sight and seven observation periscopes, while the gunner has a day sight and three observation periscopes.{{Sfn | Foss | 2004 | p = 277}} [[Image:Tam paz.jpg|right|thumb|Argentine VCTPs during peacekeeping operations in Croatia]] Variants also include the ''Vehículo de Combate de Artillería de 155 mm'' (155 mm Artillery Combat Vehicle), or VCA 155, and the ''Vehículo de Combate Transporte de Mortero'' (Mortar Transport Combat Vehicle), or VCTM. The VCA-155 is an elongated TAM chassis fitted with [[Oto Melara]]'s [[Palmaria (artillery)|Palmaria]] {{convert|155|mm|in|adj=on|abbr=in}} [[self-propelled howitzer]] [[Gun turret|turret]].{{Sfn | Foss | 2006 | p = 11}} It carries 28 projectiles, 23 of which are stored in the turret bustle.{{Sfn | de Mazarrasa | 1996 | p = 48}} The VCTM carries an AM-50 {{convert|120|mm|in|adj=on|abbr=in}} internal mortar, which has a range of {{convert|9,500|m|ft|2|sp=us}} and a rate of fire of 8 to 12 shots per minute. Based on the TAM chassis, the ''Vehículo de Combate Puesto de Mando'' (command combat vehicle), or VCPC, is another variant designed in 1982.{{Sfn | de Mazarrasa | 1996 | pp = 43–44}} The ''Vehículo de Combate Lanzacohetes'' (Rocket launcher combat vehicle), or VCLC, designed in 1986, is also based on the TAM chassis and can be fitted with both {{convert|160|mm|in|adj=on|abbr=in}} and {{convert|350|mm|in|1|adj=on|abbr=in}} rockets. {{Sfn | Foss | 2006 | p = 11}} A combat ambulance, ''Vehículo de Combate Ambulancia'' (VCA), and an [[armored recovery vehicle]], ''Vehículo de Combate de Recuperación'' (VCRT) are other combat variants of the tank. {| class="wikitable" text-align:left;" summary="Characteristics of TAM variants" |+ TAM variants {{Sfn | de Mazarrasa | 1996 | pp = 56–63}} |- style="vertical-align:bottom; border-bottom:1px solid #999;" ! ! style="text-align:left;" | VCTP ! style="text-align:left;" | VCA 155 ! style="text-align:left;" | VCTM ! style="text-align:left;" | VCPC ! style="text-align:left;" | VCLC ! style="text-align:left;" | VCA ! style="text-align:left;" | VCRT |- ! style="text-align:right;" | Weight | 28.2 [[Tonne|t]] (31.1 [[Short ton|tons]]) | 40 t (44.1 tons) | 26 t (28.7 tons) | 25 t (27.6 tons) | 32 t (35.3 tons) | 28 t (30.9 tons) | 32 t (35.3 tons) |- ! style="text-align:right;" | Armament | [[Rheinmetall MK 20 Rh 202|20 mm (.79 in) Rh-202]] autocannon | 155 mm (6.1 in) L/41 [[howitzer]] | 120 mm (4.72 in) mortar | 7.62 mm (0.3 in.) Economic problems, however, ended production in 1983 with only 150 TAMs and 100 VCTPs built. These vehicles were produced by an Argentine company, ''Tanque Argentino Mediano Sociedad del Estado'' (or TAMSE) founded by the government in March 1980. 70% of the TAM's components were manufactured in Argentina, while the 30% manufactured in Germany corresponded to the transmission, optics and fire control system. In 1983, 20 TAMs and 26 VCTPs were delivered to the Argentine Army after an original order of 80 TAMs by Peru was canceled due to budgetary issues. In 1991, TAMSE and the TAM production line were shut down, although in 1994 TAMSE was reactivated to complete an order for 120 of both TAMs and VCTPs to replace the M4 Shermans in the 2nd Armored Cavalry Brigade of the Argentine Army. By 1995 the Argentine Army was equipped with 200 TAM tanks and 216 VCTP and VCPC armored vehicles.{{Sfn | de Mazarrasa | 1996 | pp = 16–18}} Although 25 VCA-155s were originally planned for production starting in 1990,{{Sfn | de Mazarrasa | 1996 | p = 45}} only 19 were completed and delivered by 1995, along with 50 VCTMs.{{Sfn | de Mazarrasa | 1996 | p = 18}} No other variants of the TAM, including the VCLC, VAC and VCRT were put into production due to budget restrictions.{{Sfn | Foss | 2002 | p = 250}} The TAMSE plant is a {{convert|9,600|m2|sqft|sigfig=4|adj=on|sp=us}} facility. The factory is completely covered, with two warehouses for storing components, quality control laboratories, a project office, an engine test room and a firing range. Also participating in the production of TAM and variant components were Argentine companies Military Factories General San Martín (manufacturing the chassis), Río Tercero (turret and armament) and Bator Cocchis, S.A.{{Sfn | de Mazarrasa | 1996 | p = 17}} == Export and combat history == [[Image:VCLC MRL 160 mm.JPG|right|thumb|VCLC during the Argentine Army Exhibition in 2008]] The TAM has never been exported, although a number of nations were interested in buying it. In 1981, [[Malaysia]] signed a contract for 102 vehicles of the TAM family, including the tank, VCTP and VCRT (renaming these Lion, Tiger and Elephant, respectively). None of these vehicles were delivered and Malaysia chose instead to procure Poland's [[PT-91]].{{Sfn | Foss | 2004 | p = 53}} In mid-1983, Peru established a contract for 80 TAMs. Due to budgetary problems the order was canceled after 20 tanks had been completed. A similar order was established by [[Panama]] in 1984, and was canceled as well.{{Sfn | de Mazarrasa | 1996 | pp = 17–18}} In 1989 the TAM competed in a tank procurement order from [[Ecuador]], alongside the American [[Stingray light tank]], the [[Austria]]n [[SK-105 Kürassier]] and the French AMX-13-105 light tank. The TAM achieved 950 out of 1,000 points, while its closest competitor earned 750 points, but in the end Ecuador did not procure any of the vehicles presented.{{Sfn | de Mazarrasa | 1996 | pp = 17–18}} In the Middle East, both [[Iran]] and [[Saudi Arabia]] expressed interest in the TAM. The Iranian deal fell through after [[Saudi Arabia]] and [[Iraq]] successfully appealed to Germany to cancel the order.{{Sfn | de Mazarrasa | 1996 | pp = 17–18}} TAMSE attempted to sell 60 tanks through a Panamanian company, Agrometal, offering this company a commission worth 10% of the contract's price. This failed when TAMSE lowered the price of the vehicles, angering the Iranian government, which subsequently canceled the offer.{{Sfn | Garasino | 1999}} The Saudi Arabian deal was scrapped when [[Israel]] appealed to Germany to cancel the order.{{Sfn | de Mazarrasa | 1996 | pp = 17–18}} Failing to export the tank, the Argentine government closed the TAMSE fabrication plant in 1995.{{Sfn | Clarín | 1998}} The TAM did not participate in the [[Falklands War]], as it had not entered service before the end of the conflict. Seventeen VCTPs were deployed with an Argentina battalion to Yugoslavia during [[United Nations]] peacekeeping operations. {{Sfn | de Mazarrasa | 1996 | p = 18}} ==Users== ;{{flagicon|Argentina}}
